conclusion: Determine the height that object A rises and the spring constant k2 of spring C.
Mass of A is 2 kg, spring constant of spring B is 200 N/m, distance ab is 60 cm or 0.6 m.
Initial compression of spring B due to gravity is calculated as x1 = mg/k1 = 9.8 cm.
When the right endpoint of spring C is at b, tension in spring B equals gravitational force on A, meaning spring B is not stretched or compressed.
A rises a distance equal to the initial compression x1, which is 9.8 cm.
The height h that A rises is 9.8 cm.
Total length of the rope segment that moves horizontally is 60 cm, vertical displacement of A is 9.8 cm.
Using Pythagorean theorem, calculate deformation of spring C as x2 = 50.2 cm.
Spring constant k2 is calculated using k2 * x2 = mg, resulting in k2 â‰ˆ 39.04 N/m.
Final answer: height that object A rises is 9.8 cm, spring constant k2 of spring C is approximately 39.04 N/m.
